subject: BoJ Minutes from October Meeting stated most members recognized there had been no further increase in the possibility that the momentum toward achieving the price stability target would be lost and it is appropriate to maintain current purchase guidelines
content:
Says

Some members noted BoJ must not hesitate to take additional easing if there was a greater chance momentum to reaching price target was lost.

Members agreed that the economy had been on a moderate expanding trend, with a virtuous cycle from income to spending operating, although exports, production, and business sentiment continued to be affected by the slowdown in overseas economies.

Full link: http://www.boj.or.jp/en/mopo/mpmsche_minu/minu_2019/g191031.pdf
analysis_details: • As a reminder, the BoJ kept all monetary policy settings unchanged as expected at the meeting but tweaked the forward guidance to more clearly signal future chance of rate cut, in which it expects short and long-term rates to stay at current or lower levels as long as needed. Furthermore, there was a more recent meeting held last week in which the central bank kept policy settings unchanged also.

subject: DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese Premier Li said China will study further steps to lower financing costs via RRR cuts, targeted RRR cuts, discounting and re-lending, according to state media. (Newswires)

 

FX

  • Canadian GDP (Oct) M/M -0.1% Exp. 0.0% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)

 

US

CNBC's Tausche stated that US President Trump's advisers have been saying to not proceed with auto tariffs until the 2020 election has finished. (Newswires)

  • US Durable Goods (Nov) -2.0% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)
  • US New Home Sales-Units (Nov) 0.719M vs. Exp. 0.734M (Prev. 0.733M, Rev. 0.710M)

 

MARKET RECAP

Boeing (BA) led gains on the Dow after it's Muilenberg resigned as CEO, effective immediately as both CEO and Board Director; current Chairman Calhoun is to take over the CEO role (and retain the President role) from January 13th, with CFO Smith serving as interim CEO until then. Apache (APA) rose over 10% after it announced a JV with Total (FP FP) to explore and develop Block 58 offshore Suriname, where both parties will hold a 50% working interest; Total will pay a USD 100mln bonus as part of the deal. JD.com (JD) was among the NDX outperformers after sources suggested it is eyeing an IPO of its logistics unit, which could reportedly fetch between USD 8-10bln. Tesla (TSLA) was higher after sources said it reportedly came to an agreement with Chinese banks for a five-year loan facility of up to CNY 10bln (USD 1.4bln). Sarepta Therapeutics (SRPT) surged over 8% after announcing it entered into a USD 1.15bln licensing agreement with Roche (ROGN SW, RHHBY) for the latter to provide exclusive commercial rights outside the US for SRPT’s SRP-9001, an investigational gene therapy for DMD. Disney (DIS) traded in the red after its latest Star Wars movie disappointed at the box office over the weekend; although the launch was successful, it was considerably less than the opening of the prior two movies in the saga; the launch bought in USD 176mln this weekend, in line with expectations, however some had anticipated it could bring in more than USD 200mln. Uber (UBER) also traded lower after its co-founder Kalnick sold more than 90% of his stake in the company over the last seven weeks, according to filings. Carmax (KMX) continued to the downside after disappointing earnings reported on Friday. SPX +0.1% at 3224, DJI +0.3% at 28552, NDX +0.2% at 8696.

Yields were higher across the curve (by 1-3bps at settlement) in thin, holiday-trading conditions, with the T-Note future remaining within an 11-tick range; the curve was a touch flatter, however, but by under 1bps. The US' sale of 2-year notes was lacklustre, at the very least; the auction stopped on the screws, though cover was the softest in 11 years, signalling very little interest in the last 2s auction of the year. Dealer participation was beneath recent averages, directs was in line with recent averages, while the indirect bid was beneath recent averages. Note: The Treasury will also be selling USD 41bln in 5s on Tuesday, as well as USD 32bln of 7s on Thursday, with this week's auctions set to raise a net USD 31.7bln at the month-end settlement. T-notes (H0) settled 5 ticks lower at 128-03.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 23rd December 2019: China to roll-back some tariffs; durables miss; Canada GDP contracts in Oct
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Crude up, Dollar flat
  • REAR VIEW: China to roll-back some tariffs on imports from WTO partners; US durable goods, new home sales miss; Canada GDP contracts in October; soft 2-year Tsy auction; Boeing CEO quits.
  • COMING UP: Richmond Fed, API inventories, Japan services PMI, US 5-year auction. Note: The RANsquawk desk will be closed through the holidays; our desk opening hours can be accessed here.

* US/CHINA: China said it would continue to open-up its economy, lowering tariffs on imports from WTO partners worth around USD 389bln from 1st January. The tariffs are to be lowered on 859 products, the Ministry of Finance said. Analysts suggested that the move was designed to contrast with the protectionist approach of US President Trump. The list of goods on which tariffs will be lowered included frozen pork, as China grapples with high pork prices. Others noted that China is taking measure to boost growth amid risks that GDP growth could fall sub-6.0% next year.

* US DURABLE GOODS (NOV): Headline durable goods unexpectedly fell in November (-2.0% versus an expected +1.5%); the ex-transport measure was unchanged, against expectations of a small rise. The data was driven lower by defense aircraft orders; core capital goods rose a touch, with the annualised rate rising in November, which analysts at Oxford Economics said signals modestly firmer momentum approaching year-end, but not a significant change in the downbeat environment for business investment. The consultancy notes that shipments of nondefense capital goods stripping out aircrafts (which forms part of the data on business equipment which feeds into GDP) declined by 0.3% M/M, and OxEco says this could suggest another contraction in equipment spending in Q4. "We expect industrial momentum will remain muted in 2020 amid an environment of sluggish global growth, persistent trade policy uncertainty, a US strong dollar, and subdued corporate profitability," Oxford Economics wrote, "Boeing’s decision to halt production of the 737 MAX will present a continuing drag on orders."

* US NEW HOME SALES (NOV): It was a miss, with annualised new home sales coming in at 719k in November, short of the expected 734k; additionally, October's data was revised down to 710k from an initially reported 733k. The supply of new homes, however, fell to 5.4 months from 5.5 months in October. Wells Fargo said that although this level of sales was not quite as strong as expected, strength in the NAHB/Wells Fargo Homebuilders Survey suggests that the upward trend in sales remains intact.

* CANADA GDP: Canadian GDP growth declined by 0.1% M/M in October -- the first monthly decline in 8-months -- from a prior 0.1% M/M; the Street was looking for an unchanged reading. Canadian bank RBC suggests that transitory factors may be in play: "Part (although not all) of a sharp drop in manufacturing output was due to Canadian auto-sector production shutdowns as a drop in US production tied to an autoworker strike in September and October spilled over into Canada," the bank explains, "that drag might be expected to reverse in the near-term, although with the more permanent shutdown of most production at Oshawa's GM plant still to come." The bank also notes that not all transitory factors were on the downside in October: "The drop in goods output was also despite a bounce-back in North Atlantic oil production that reversed a large drop earlier in the summer, but still, goods-sector output, particularly manufacturing production, has been soft for some time, both in Canada and abroad as global supply chains were impacted by rising US-China tariffs -- an easing in those tensions late this year means that headwind should ease somewhat going forward." RBC also believes that service-sector output appears reasonably solid still. It argues that, while consumer spending growth is modest, the 1.1% pullback in the retail sector still looks over-stated relative to household income growth trends - notwithstanding an ugly-looking employment report in Canada in November. "But a big pullback in wholesale sales in October was also in part impacted by the auto-sector strike. Outside of those components, most service-sector industries continued to grow in October, and output among service-producers was still up 2.0% from a year ago." The data was of interest given the BOC has adopted a hawkish tact in recent commentary, although data has been coming in softer. RBC's own GDP model is tracking growth sub-1.00%: "We are now tracking an increase in Q4 GDP of less than a percent, below the Bank of Canada's call for a 1.3%, and our 1.4% call," and adds that "monthly economic data in Canada is notoriously volatile, but still, the softer numbers in October/November data to-date will only increase focus, including at the Bank of Canada, near-term economic data reports, and particularly whether any of the recent weakness is reversed."

* T-NOTES (H0) SETTLE 5 TICKS LOWER AT 128-03: Yields were higher across the curve (by 1-3bps at settlement) in thin, holiday-trading conditions, with the T-Note future remaining within an 11 tick range; the curve was a touch flatter, however, but by under 1bps. The US' sale of 2-year notes was lacklustre, at the very least; the auction stopped on the screws, though cover was the softest in 11 years, signalling very little interest in the last 2s auction of the year. Dealer participation was beneath recent averages, directs was in line with recent averages, while the indirect bid was beneath recent averages. Note: The Treasury will also be selling USD 41bln in 5s on Tuesday, as well as USD 32bln of 7s on Thursday, with this week's auctions set to raise a net USD 31.7bln at the month-end settlement.

* WTI (G0) SETTLES USD 0.08 HIGHER AT 60.52/BBL; BRENT (G0) SETTLES USD 0.25 HIGHER AT USD 66.39/BBL. There was a thin, holiday-feel to trade on Monday; the crude complex settled flat/slightly higher on light volumes, with desks attributing the price action to pre-holiday book-squaring. The thin liquidity saw choppy price action throughout the day, ahead of the Brent option expiry tonight which could be a factor in todays’ action, also. Earlier, the Russian energy minister said OPEC+ may gradually ease limits on production levels after Q1, though impressed that a continuation of the current arrangements was also a possibility (NOTE: Opec is due to meet on 5/6 March). One desk said that, rather than a scoop on a possible policy shift this comes across like a variation on the standard 'it's too soon to decide and all options are on the table' statement designed to respond to the question without actually revealing anything. Elsewhere, traders were keeping an eye on geopolitical events; Saudi Arabia and Kuwait reportedly could agree to renew oil output in the shared neutral zone along the border between the countries by year-end; the two would not add net supply, but would reallocate their OPEC quotas between the expanded list of fields. Meanwhile, there is still attention on Libya, where the battle for Triploi might have an impact on crude output, and additionally, attention on Iran, which is continuing with punchy rhetoric around its nuclear programme.

* CLOSING LEVELS: * CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +0.1% at 3224, DJI +0.3% at 28552, NDX +0.2% at 8696. SECTORS: Consumer discretionary -0.1%, consumer staples -0.3%, energy +1.1%, financials -0.2%, health care +0.3%, industrials +0.6%, IT +0.3%, materials +0.4%, telecoms -0.3%, utilities -1.0%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) led gains on the Dow after it's Muilenberg resigned as CEO, effective immediately as both CEO and Board Director; current Chairman Calhoun is to take over the CEO role (and retain the President role) from January 13th, with CFO Smith serving as interim CEO until then. Apache (APA) rose over 10% after it announced a JV with Total (FP FP) to explore and develop Block 58 offshore Suriname, where both parties will hold a 50% working interest; Total will pay a USD 100mln bonus as part of the deal. JD.com (JD) was among the NDX outperformers after sources suggested it is eyeing an IPO of its logistics unit, which could reportedly fetch between USD 8-10bln. Tesla (TSLA) was higher after sources said it reportedly came to an agreement with Chinese banks for a five-year loan facility of up to CNY 10bln (USD 1.4bln). Sarepta Therapeutics (SRPT) surged over 8% after announcing it entered into a USD 1.15bln licensing agreement with Roche (ROGN SW, RHHBY) for the latter to provide exclusive commercial rights outside the US for SRPT’s SRP-9001, an investigational gene therapy for DMD. Disney (DIS) traded in the red after its latest Star Wars movie disappointed at the box office over the weekend; although the launch was successful, it was considerably less than the opening of the prior two movies in the saga; the launch bought in USD 176mln this weekend, in line with expectations, however some had anticipated it could bring in more than USD 200mln. Uber (UBER) also traded lower after its co-founder Kalnick sold more than 90% of his stake in the company over the last seven weeks, according to filings. Carmax (KMX) continued to the downside after disappointing earnings reported on Friday.

* FX WRAP: Ranges were thin today amid holiday conditions, however, GBP continued to sell off, breaching 1.30 to the downside as the post-election slide continues (no-deal risk is coming back into pricing after the government legislated against any transition extension beyond end-2020. CAD also traded weaker after data showed the Canadian economy contracting in October; however, losses were pared throughout the session, with some suggesting it could be that the contraction was due to transitory factors. A rise in oil prices in the middle of the session might also could have contributed to the CAD’s downside, however, analysts highlight the correlation between Canadian Dollar and oil prices has somewhat dissipated recently. DXY saw choppy trade, where the weakness in the aforementioned currencies initially buoyed the buck despite poor durables data, however as CAD regained its poise, the DXY was pushed beneath its 200dma at 97.70 to turn negative. Antipodes traded firmer today, with higher copper prices said to aid the AUD. AUDUSD traded above its 200dma of 0.6903 after breaching the figure to the upside early in the morning, a level it resides around heading into the last Asia session before Christmas. EMFX was mixed and generally flat amid the holiday period, however BRL outperformed after US President Trump reportedly offered to remove a threat to impose tariffs on Brazilian steel and aluminium.

subject: Banxico Governor De Leon says the central bank is not committed to rate moves in any direction and notes inflation is clearly on a downward trend but risks remain
analysis_details:
• The latest Banxico rate decision cut rates by 25bps, where only one member voted for a deeper 50bp cut as oppose to the two members who voted for a 50bp cut at the previous meeting. Heading into the meeting, analysts cautioned a 50bp move would be too much at the minute given inflation is currently at the 3% target, amid an improved USMCA and US China outlook, it could spur unnecessary inflation given the recent 20% minimum wage hike.
  • The latest Banxico statement from its rate decision highlighted the current environment continues to present risks that could affect the macroeconomic conditions in the country and its potential for growth.
  • It reiterated balance of risks remain tilted to the downside in the uncertain environment
  • Noting, headline and core inflation in 2020 will reflect greater slack in the economy and higher than expected minimum wage hike, that could see inflation moderately above where it has been in the previous quarterly report.

subject: WTI (G0) SETTLES USD 0.08 HIGHER AT 60.52/BBL; BRENT (G0) SETTLES USD 0.25 HIGHER AT USD 66.39/BBL
analysis_details: • There was a thin, holiday-feel to trade on Monday; the crude complex settled slightly higher on light volumes, with desks attributing the price action to pre-holiday book-squaring. The thin liquidity saw choppy price action throughout the day, ahead of the Brent option expiry tonight which could be a factor in todays’ action, also. Earlier, the Russian energy minister said OPEC+ may gradually ease limits on production levels after Q1, though impressed that a continuation of the current arrangements was also a possibility (NOTE: Opec is due to meet on 5/6 March). One desk said that, rather than a scoop on a possible policy shift this comes across like a variation on the standard 'it's too soon to decide and all options are on the table' statement designed to respond to the question without actually revealing anything. Elsewhere, traders were keeping an eye on geopolitical events; Saudi Arabia and Kuwait reportedly could agree to renew oil output in the shared neutral zone along the border between the countries by year-end; the two would not add net supply, but would reallocate their OPEC quotas between the expanded list of fields. Meanwhile, there is still attention on Libya, where the battle for Triploi might have an impact on crude output, and additionally, attention on Iran, which is continuing with punchy rhetoric around its nuclear programme.

subject: ANALYSIS: New home sales miss, although analyst says upward trend remains in tact
analysis_details: It was a miss, with annualised new home sales coming in at 719k in November, short of the expected 734k; additioanlly, October's data was revised down to 710k from an initially reported 733k. The supply of new homes, however, fell to 5.4 months from 5.5 months in October. Wells Fargo said that although this level of sales was not quite as strong as expected, strength in the NAHB/Wells Fargo Homebuilders Survey suggests that the upward trend in sales remains intact.

subject: ANALYSIS: Defense aircraft orders weighs on US durable goods
analysis_details: Headline durable goods unexpectedly fell in November (-2.0% versus an expected +1.5%); the ex-transport measure was unchanged, against expectations of a small rise. The data was driven lower by defense aircraft orders; core capital goods rose a touch, with the annualised rate rising in November, which analysts at Ocford Economics said signals modestly firmer momentum approaching year-end, but not a significant change in the downbeat environment for business investment. The consultancy notes that shipments of nondefense capital goods stripping out aircrafts (which forms part of the data on business equipment which feeds into GDP) declined by 0.3% M/M, and OxEco says this could suggest another contraction in equipment spending in Q4. "We expect industrial momentum will remain muted in 2020 amid an environment of sluggish global growth, persistent trade policy uncertainty, a US strong dollar, and subdued corporate profitability," Oxford Economics wrote, "Boeing’s decision to halt production of the 737 MAX will present a continuing drag on orders."

subject: ANALYSIS: GDP another soft data-point out of Canada
analysis_details: Canadian GDP growth declined by 0.1% M/M in October -- the first monthly decline in 8-months -- from a prior 0.1% M/M; the Street was looking for an unchanged reading. Canadian bank RBC suggests that transitory factors may be in play: "Part (although not all) of a sharp drop in manufacturing output was due to Canadian auto-sector production shutdowns as a drop in US production tied to an autoworker strike in September and October spilled over into Canada," the bank explains, "that drag might be expected to reverse in the near-term, although with the more permanent shutdown of most production at Oshawa's GM plant still to come." The bank also notes that not all transitory factors were on the downside in October: "The drop in goods output was also despite a bounce-back in North Atlantic oil production that reversed a large drop earlier in the summer, but still, goods-sector output, particularly manufacturing production, has been soft for some time, both in Canada and abroad as global supply chains were impacted by rising US-China tariffs -- an easing in those tensions late this year means that headwind should ease somewhat going forward." RBC also believes that service-setor output appears reasonably solid still. It argues that, while consumer spending growth is modest, the 1.1% pullback in the retail sector still looks over-stated relative to household income growth trends - notwithstanding an ugly-looking employment report in Canada in November. "But a big pullback in wholesale sales in October was also in part impacted by the auto-sector strike. Outside of those components, most service-sector industries continued to grow in October, and output among service-producers was still up 2.0% from a year ago." The data was of interest given the BOC has adopted a hawkish tact in recent commentary, although data has been coming in softer. RBC's own GDP model is tracking growth sub-1.00%: "We are now tracking an increase in Q4 GDP of less than a percent, below the Bank of Canada's call for a 1.3%, and our 1.4% call," and adds that "monthly economic data in Canada is notoriously volatile, but still, the softer numbers in October/November data to-date will only increase focus, including at the Bank of Canada, near-term economic data reports, and particularly whether any of the recent weakness is reversed."

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar durable despite dire data, but Loonie limp and Sterling still swooning
content:
USD

The Dollar is holding up fairly well in the face of a hefty US durable goods miss vs consensus and sub-forecast new home sales, partly due to more pronounced weakness elsewhere and perhaps on bullish technical impulses as the DXY hovers around the 200 DMA (97.700) and within striking distance of the next upside chart resistance ahead of 98.000 (like the December 6 high at 97.844 and 97.850). Note also, an uptick in US Treasury yields amidst slightly less flattening may be supportive as the index hugs the top of a 97.820-578 range.

CAD/GBP

In contrast to its US counterpart, the Loonie is licking wounds again in wake of more downbeat Canadian data, as GDP contracted 0.1% m/m in October compared to forecasts for stagnation and extended a run of worrying economic releases ironically since December’s BoC policy meeting that was accompanied by a relatively confident or less cautious assessment of growth and the outlook. Usd/Cad appears to have broken free from the shackles of 1.3150 and is on the verge of testing last Friday’s high (1.3179) before setting sights on 1.3200. However, the Loonie is not the worst performing major on Monday given more heavy losses for the Pound as the quite remarkable post-UK election unwind continues. Cable has now lost grip/sight of the 1.3000 handle and extended its retracement to just a few pips above 1.2900 when stops were tripped on a break below last week’s base (1.2979) for a cumulative reversal of more than 6 big figures, while Eur/Gbp’s resurgence reached circa 0.8580 vs some 300 pips below at one stage well before a decent option expiry at 0.8570 (800+ mn) rolled off. No fresh fundamental catalysts, but it goes without saying that the technical landscape for Sterling is turning increasingly bearish as GE euphoria morphs back into Brexit uncertainty with a dose of no deal risk.

NZD/AUD 

Ahead of the G10 pack from the outset, Nzd/Usd has now eclipsed Aud/Usd to nudge the Aud/Nzd cross back down under 1.04500, as the Kiwi maintains a firmer grip of 0.6600+ status in relation to the Aussie beyond 0.6900. Nevertheless, both have inched a bit closer to nearest upside objectives in the form of mid-month peaks and Aud/Usd remains ‘comfortably’ above the 200 DMA (0.6905) amidst ongoing positivity surrounding US-China trade deal phase 1 and recent Antipodean data that has prompted some paring of RBA/RBNZ easing expectations.

EUR/CHF/JPY/NOK/SEK

The Euro has been grinding higher since the aforementioned US data, albeit belatedly, and seems poised to test the resolve and psychological will of offers at 1.1100 after surviving a downturn to the 30 DMA (1.1069), and without any option-related supply/hedging related to nearly 1 bn between the big figure and 1.1110. However, volumes are getting increasingly light and it remains to be seen whether buyers have enough conviction or interest to take on the next round number. Indeed, the Franc has been unable to pierce 0.9800 and Yen is still mired in a 109.35-53 band, while the Scandi Kronas remain mixed after the final Riskbank and Norges Bank policy meetings of the year confirmed a one more rate hike and done from the former, but a somewhat unforeseen 10 bp tightening from the latter at the end of the projected depo path. Eur/Nok is around 9.9200 vs Eur/Sek skirting with 10.4500.

 

EM

Not much in terms of independent drivers or region-specific impulses, bar China’s commitment to lowering more import tariffs, regardless of whether the 1st part of the US trade accord is signed off or not, and mildly softer than anticipated Mexican inflation for 1st half of December. Hence, Usd/EM pairs have been rangy either side or in proximity to recent ranges/levels such as 7.0000 for the Yuans, 14.2500 for the Rand, 5.9400 for the Lira, 19.0000 for the Mexican Peso, 4.0800 for the Real, and last but by no means least 62.3500 for the outperforming Rouble.

subject: US Equity Open Summary: Equities open higher continuing the Christmas rally with DJ buoyed by BA CEO change
content:
INDIVIDUAL STOCK MOVERS: 

Gainers

  • Apache (APA) +8.75% after it announced a joint venture with Total (FP FP) to explore and develop Block 58 offshore Suriname, where both parties will hold a 50% working interest. Total will pay a USD 100mln bonus as part of the deal.
  • Boeing (BA) +3.2% after it's CEO Muilenberg resigned, effective immediately, amid the fallout regarding its 737 MAX jet.
  • JD.com (JD) +3% after source reports suggest it is eyeing an IPO of its Logistics unit, which could reportedly fetch up to USD 8-10bln

Losers

  • Carmax (KMX) -2.5% continuing its demise from its earnings report on Friday
  • Disney (DIS) -1.2% after its "Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker" box office weekend, although successful, it was considerably less than the opening of the prior two in the saga.  The launch bought in  USD 176mln this weekend, in line with expectations, however some had anticipated it could bring in more than USD 200mln.
  • Uber (UBER) -1.2% after its co-founder Kalnick sold more than 90% stake in his company over the last seven weeks, according to SEC filings
analysis_details: • The three major US equity bourses open higher with outperformance in Dow Jones & Nasdaq 100, both up 0.3%, following Boeing (BA) CEO resignation amid the fallout regarding the 737 MAX jet. Nasdaq performing well with gains in JD.com (JD) after reports it is in early discussion regarding an IPO of its logistics unit, which could fetch between USD 8-10bln, according to sources. Tesla (TSLA) also higher after source reports suggest it has come to an agreement with Chinese banks for a 5-year loan facility of up to USD 1.4bln (CNY 10bln). Industrials are the outperforming story on the back of Boeing (BA). Utilities and Energy the underperforming sectors today with the former paring some of last weeks gains and energy hit by lower energy prices. However, losses are limited, likely being helped by gains in Apache (APA) who trade 8% higher after agreeing to a 50/50 JV with Total (FP FP).

analysis_details:
• Co. are 7.8% of the DJIA
  • CNBC's Faber speculates that the Co's CEO Muilenburg may not be CEO for much longer

RECENT BOEING NEWS: Following the halting of 737 MAX production, reports in WSJ state that General Electric’s (GE) JV with Safran (SAF FP), CFM International, has reportedly agreed on a deal to build more Airbus (AIR FP) engines to help offset the 737 MAX shutdown. Boeing’s current production of the jet is 42 per month, and some estimate its backlog will sit at 400 by the year end. Note, when Boeing announced a production cut of the jet to 42 from 52, it cut GE’s quarterly cash flow by USD 400mln. Analysts at Capital Economics highlight the decision to halt production could result in a hit to the manufacturing sector, adding if it continues they expect it to knock up to 0.5ppts annualised off of Q1 GDP if the shutdown lasted for the whole quarter, adding if they do decide to lay off workers or workers become furloughed (against the company’s initial statement) the damage could be even worse. Further, United Airlines (UAL) announced today that it has pulled the 737 MAX jet from its schedule until June. Previously the airline had the return of the jet scheduled to March. The report added to downside for Boeing (BA) which was already lower today following reports its space unit’s Starliner entered the wrong orbit to dock with the ISS, however, BoeingSpace later reported the Starline is now in safe and stable orbit, and thus pared back the losses from the UAL reports.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: debt back on the front foot, Dollar holding in
content: The early NA data has prompted a bit more price action, with US durable goods living up to its notorious name of defying expectations at -2% vs 1.5% forecast, while Canadian GDP adds to the growing list of downside misses including jobs, manufacturing and retail sales. Hence, bonds have bounced across the board, and Gilts to a marginal new Liffe session high (132.25), as Usd/Cad probes higher off the 1.3150 axis towards last Friday’s 1.3179 peak. However, the DXY is holding relatively firm irrespective of the dire data, with the ongoing Cable collapse helping to keep the index afloat near best levels (97.820) and a whisker above the 200 DMA (97.700).

Raytheon (RTN) received a USD 1.03bln government contract for Standard missile-6 full rate production requirements, spares and round design agent. RTN also awarded a USD 1.02bln government contract modification.
  • This weeks Barron’s articles highlight that China Mobile (CHL) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) stock is cheap, whilst also notes hurdles may be causing some investors to overlook Becton Dickinson (BDX) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment), “a solid company”.

DOW

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) had its PT increased at Wedbush to USD 350 from USD 325, where analyst Daniel Ives maintained an outperform rating on the company. The analyst believes iPhone demand “remains comfortably ahead” of the street consensus. He also highlighted 5G smartphones “will open up the floodgates on iPhone upgrades across the board” which the street continues to underestimate, he writes.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced its Starliner orbital test has completed and landed back on American soil, noting it will provide a great deal of useful data, despite not being able to dock with the ISS.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) and Hess (HES) announced it has started oil production from the Liza field offshore Guyana ahead of schedule. XOM also announced it discovered oil offshore Guyana at the Majo-1 well, noting the discovery adds to the 6bln bbls of oil equivalent on the Stabroek block previously estimated.
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) have been found non-guilt by a jury in St. Louis, who found that the pharmaceutical giant’s talcum powder did not cause disease. Note, JNJ have many more trials scheduled next year.
  • Pfizer Inc. (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and GlaxoSmithKline’s (GSK) ViiV Healthcare, received a complete response letter from the FDA on its application for cabotegravir and rilpivrine for treatment of HIV-1. Note, GSK are the majority shareholder, and PFE are a shareholder.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) announced it is planning to focus on its stores rather than an e-commerce operation, noting the supercentres could be the heart of a web of businesses all working together to attract shoppers. (WSJ) 

NASDAQ 100

  • JD.com (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is reportedly in early discussions for a possible IPO to its logistics company which could fetch up to USD 8-10bln, according to sources.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) has reportedly come to an agreement with Chinese banks for a 5-year loan facility of up to CNY 10bln (USD 1.4bln), according to sources. The loan is to be used to roll-over a prior loan as well as their China operations including its Shanghai facility. Elsewhere, the automakers manufacturing executive Bruggeman is to leave the company, according to German Press. Tesla also reported reached a deal to purchase a plot of land outside of Berlin for a new Gigafactory.

S&P 500

NOTE: Live Nation (LYV), Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) and Steris (STE), replace affiliated Managers Group (AMG), Trip Advisor (TRIP), and Macerich (MAC) in the index today.

  • Apache Corporation (APA) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) and Total (FP FP) announced a joint venture to explore and develop Block 58 offshore Suriname, where both parties will hold a 50% working interest. Total will pay a USD 100mln bonus as part of the deal.
  • BlackRock (BLK) (Financials/Asset Management & Custody Banks) reportedly agreed to start a wealth management JV in China, where Singapore’s Temasek Holdings and China Construction Bank would be partners with BlackRock.
  • FedEx Corporation (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) director Edwardson has purchased 10,000 shares of common stock for USD 148.22/shr.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is in talks with NHTSA regarding the deployment of a limited number of self-driving cars without steering wheels.
  • Host Hotels & Resorts (HST) (Real Estate/Hotel & Resort REITs) Chairman sold 160k shares of common stock for USD 18.51/shr.
  • MGM Resorts International (MGM) (Consumer Discretionary/Casinos & Gaming) announced its Circus Circus Las Vegas sale for USD 825mln has now closed. The final offer is subject to price adjustments.
  • TJX Companies Inc. (TJX) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel Retail) is facing a call from Senator Chuck Schumer for a federal probe of TJX stores for selling recalled products. TJX responded noting some products were mistakenly left on shelves, and that it is working to prevent a recurrence.

OTHER

  • AquaVenture (WAAS) (Utilities/Water Utilities) announced it has entered into a definitive agreement to be acquired by Culligan for USD 27.10/shr in cash, valued at USD 1.1bln. Friday’s closing price stood at USD 21.76, ~ a 25% premium.
  • Aurora Cannabis (ACB) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced it has taken steps to reduce debt and boost liquidity as it is to roll out its “Cannabis 2.0”, a line of newly legalised products, reports CNBC. Elsewhere, its Chief Corporate Officer Battley has stepped down. MKM highlight this does not send a strong message to investors and adds to the turmoil. 
  • BeiGene (BGNE) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced the China National Medical Products Administration has accepted a supplemental NDA for Revlimid in combination with Rituximab for patients with relapsed indolent lymphoma.
  • Bunge (BG) (Consumer Staples/Food Products) has come to an agreement with Seara Alimentos in Brazil, which includes three production plants and the brands used in the products. Financial terms were not disclosed, and it still requires regulatory approval.
  • Cincinnati Bell (CBB) (Communication Services/Diversified Telecommunication Services) is to be acquired by Brookfield Infrastructure (BIP) in a deal worth roughly USD 2.6bln, including debt. Following the agreement, each CBB share will have the right to be converted into the right to receive USD 10.50 cash, up from the USD 7.72 closing price on Friday, which represents a 36% premium.
  • Hess Midstream (HESM) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) filed to sell USD 1bln of Class A shares for holders.
  • Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) received a negative note from Bank of America, who state the most recent settlement case bring the company one step closer to bankruptcy. The latest being that creditors have upped its offer for California wildfire victims to USD 13.5bln in cash, according to a letter sent to CA Governor Newsom. Elsewhere, the co. announced it hit a crucial milestone in the 2020 General Rate Case, which funds important additional safety investments to help protect its 16mln customers. A group of those involved agreed the CPUC should approve funding for the additional protections.
  • Sangamo Therapeutics (SOMO) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced the SB-525 Haemophilia A gene therapy transfer to Pfizer (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) has been completed.
  • Sarepta Therapeutics (SRPT) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced it has entered a USD 1.15bln licensing agreement with Roche (ROGN SW, RHHBY) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) providing ROGN SW exclusive commercial rights outside the US for SRPT’s SRP-9001, an investigational gene therapy for DMD.
  • TG Therapeutics (TGTX) (Health Care/Biotechnology) has agreed to sell roughly USD 5.4mln shares to institutional investors at USD 9.20/shr.
  • Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Road&Rail) co-founder Kalanick sold more than 90% of his stake in the co. over the last seven weeks, according to SEC filings. (CNBC)

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

  • 3M (MMM) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN
  • READY CAPITAL (RC) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SANDLER O'NEILL

Downgrades

  • ROCKWELL AUTOMATION (ROK) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JPMORGAN
  • CELESTICA (CLS) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM NEUTRAL AT CITI
  • VALERITAS (VLRX) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT BTIG
  • VALERITAS (VLRX) DOWNGRADED TO MARKET PERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT OPPENHEIMER

Initiation

  • COGNIZANT (CTSH) RATED NEW SELL AT AMBIT CAPITAL PVT LTD; PT USD 65
  • CRACKER BARREL (CBRL) RATED NEW NEUTRAL AT CL KING
  • GEOPARK (GPRK) REINSTATED MARKET PERFORM AT ITAU BBA; PT USD 23
  • IAC (IAC) RATED NEW OUTPERFORM AT WEDBUSH; PT USD 295
  • MATCH GROUP (MTCH) RATED NEW NEUTRAL AT WEDBUSH; PT USD 80
  • SOLENO (SLNO) RATED NEW OUTPERFORM AT OPPENHEIMER; PT USD 10
  • X4 PHARMACEUTICALS INC (XFOR) RATED NEW OUTPERFORM AT OPPENHEIMER

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - USD Firm in Quiet Trade, GBP Correction Extends
content:
•   USD retains a firm undertone, focus on US Durable Goods orders
  •   CAD remains weak amid soft data run; Oct GDP expected flat.
  •   EUR soft but weakness may reflect year-end funding pressures.
  •   GBP retains a weak undertone as post-election weakness extends below 1.30.
  •   JPY little changed; BoJ meeting minutes released this evening.
  •   AUD out-performs on China tariff news.
  •   MXN stable below 19.00.

subject: CNBC's Tausche says US President Trump's advisers have been saying to not proceed with auto tariffs until the 2020 election has finished
analysis_details:
• 2020 election is September 3rd 
  • US President Trump is yet to impose section 232 tariffs on autos; recent rhetoric on this has been light but at the beginning of December US Commerce Secretary Ross says the US has not ruled out future tariffs on imported autos

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 23rd December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European bourses are overall little changed, though the FTSE 100 outperforms as Sterling slips
  • China is to lower import tariffs on certain products beginning January 1st in which it will cut some import tariffs on 850 items and will further lower import tariffs for some IT products from July 1st
  • North Korean launch sites reportedly look basically ready to go, while other reports note NK Leader Kim is to take a wait and see approach regarding a US deal
  • In FX, the USD slightly underperforms most G10 peers excluding Sterling which has given up the 1.30 mark vs. USD
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Durable Goods, New Home Sales, Canadian GDP and US 2yr supply

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded somewhat mixed as the region once again failed to fully join in on the Christmas cheer which had propelled Wall Street to fresh record highs on Friday, with volumes light heading into the holidays. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were varied with Australia dragged by commodity-related losses and due to the adverse effects of its recent currency appreciation, while the Japanese benchmark remained afloat but with upside capped by an indecisive JPY and after Japanese Chief Cabinet Suga clarified that they have not eased export controls on South Korea. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.4%) lacked conviction despite the announcement that China is to lower import tariffs for some products beginning January 1st and after the recent Trump-Xi call in which the leaders were said to have conducted a very good talk regarding the trade deal, although reports further noted that Chinese President Xi stated US interference is harming China’s interests and there were also downward revisions to November Chinese trade data including a wider contraction in Exports. Finally, 10yr JGBs languished firmly below the 152.00 level after the recent bear-flattening in USTs and with demand also dampened by the lack of BoJ presence in the market today. 

PBoC injected CNY 50bln via 14-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY 50bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0117 vs. Exp. 7.0119 (Prev. 7.0020)

China is to lower import tariffs on certain products beginning January 1st in which it will cut some import tariffs on 850 items and will further lower import tariffs for some IT products from July 1st. Furthermore, it was also reported that China is taking a major step to open up sectors ranging from oil and gas to telecoms and railways by easing market regulations and reducing financing costs for private companies, with the government to offer more tax breaks and broaden incentives to more firms. (Xinhua)

China Global Times tweeted that China would reduce import tariffs even without the phase-one deal as it is seeking a more cooperative and inclusive global trade environment, citing Beijing Economic Operation Association Vice Director Tian Yun. (Twitter)

China November USD-denominated trade data revisions: Trade Balance revised to 37.93B (Prev. 38.73B), Exports revised to -1.3% (Prev. -1.1%), Imports revised to 0.5% (Prev. 0.3%). (Newswires)

Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga clarified that they have not eased export controls on South Korea and that the change to controls are just procedural. (Newswires)

US  

US President Trump signed the USD 1.4tln spending bill on Friday to avert the government shutdown as expected. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB's Knot said cannot dismiss worrying prospect of current low interest rates lasting another half-decade and that low interest rate policy risks becoming counterproductive, while he added that the ECB have to reassess policy in time. (Newswires)

German Import Prices MM* (Nov) 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Syrian anti-aircraft defence fired at hostile missiles which allegedly came from Israel. (Newswires)

Center for Strategic and International Studies’ Victor Cha said possible launch sites in North Korea look that they are basically ready to go. (Twitter)

North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un is expected to take a ‘wait and see’ approach regarding making a deal with the US due to US President Trump being politically vulnerable (impeachment & 2020 election); if Trump were to win another term North Korea may be more likely to return to negotiations., according to a source familiar with North Korean leadership. Adding, that the likely hood of a proactive test is ‘very low’ as this would be too confrontational for China and Russia. (CNN)

North Korea leader Kim is said to have held a meeting with top military officials to discuss boosting the country's military capability. (Newswires)

Russian Prime Minister has ordered the Russian government to draw retaliatory measures regarding US sanctions on Nord Stream 2., Ifax. Follows on from Russian Kremlin refuses to give a timeline for the launch of the Nord Stream 2 project,adding it is too early to talk about any potential retaliation against the US but actions by the US will not go unanswered. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Tentative and mixed trade for European bourses in the final full session before Christmas [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.1%] following on from a similar APAC handover amid a lack of conviction and participants. In terms of YTD performance in Europe – FTSE MIB stands as the winner with YTD returns of just over 30% followed by the CAC 40 (+27.3%), DAX (+26.0%) and Euro Stoxx 50 (+25.7%) whilst IBEX 35 (+13.1%) and FTSE 100 (+12.8%) reside towards the bottom end of the spectrum. State-side, Nasdaq (+34.5%) leads the YTD gains followed by S&P 500 (+28.5%) and DJIA (+22.0%). Back to today’s session, FTSE 100 (+0.4%) outpaced peers as exporters benefit from a softer Sterling. Sectors also reflect an indecisive risk tone with no major standouts. In terms of individual movers: Bayer (+3.0%) rose to the top of the German index after the US government said the USD 25mln verdict on Co's Roundup case should be reversed. Lufthansa (-1.3%) shares are pressured after talks with the German Union UFO fell through and strikes are imminent, albeit the union will refrain from strike action during the busy Christmas period. Meanwhile, GSK (-0.4%) drifted off lows but remains subdued after the US FDA declined to approve Co’s long acting HIV injections after the regulator questioned the treatment’s chemistry, manufacturing and controls process but not its safety. Finally, NMC Health (+28.5%) spiked higher at the open, and have continued to strengthen, after the Co. stated it will be commencing an independent third-party review to provide additional reassurances to shareholders after activist short-seller Muddy Waters questioned the integrity of NMC’s reports. Note: tomorrows session sees Eurex and all its derivatives closer whilst cash DAX will be shut all day – the rest of the cash bourses will see an early finish (full schedule on the Newsquawk headline feed)

JD.com's (JD) logistic are considering a potential USD 8-10bln IPO., according to sources. (Newswires)

Tesla (TSLA) has reportedly agreed to a 5-year loan facility, of up to 10bln yuan with Chinese banks; to be used to roll-over a previous loan as well as their China operations including their Shanghai factory. (Newswires)

FX

AUD/NZD - The Aussie and Kiwi are still outpacing their G10 rivals and jostling for top spot in the major stakes having made firmer breaches of big figures against their US counterpart, with Aud/Usd up to 0.6920 and Nzd/Usd reaching 0.6625. Both have benefited from a mixture of short covering and technical buying after recent relatively upbeat data that has reduced or rolled back RBA/RBNZ rate cut expectations. In terms of next bullish chart targets, 0.6939 looms as long as the pair holds/closes above the 200 DMA (circa 0.6905) and 0.6636 respectively.

CHF/GBP - The Franc is in bronze position and eyeing 0.9800 vs the Buck as latest weekly Swiss sight deposits suggest less active currency intervention and the Greenback drifts down from best levels generally (DXY dipping within a narrow 97.708-578 range) amidst even thinner seasonal volumes and a softer/flatter Treasury yield curve. Similarly, Sterling is trying to take advantage of the Dollar’s dip and attempting to keep hold or sight of the 1.3000 level even though no deal Brexit risks have risen with the passing of the 1st parliament vote on PM Johnson’s WAB that includes a no transition delay clause.

EUR//JPY/CAD - All more narrowly mixed against the Usd, with the single currency mired between 1.1074-88 parameters, Yen meandering from 109.35-53 and Loonie pivoting 1.3150 ahead of Canadian GDP for the month of October that is forecast to be flat, but could disappoint given a string of bleak data since this month’s BoC meeting. Back to Eur/Usd, some option expiry interest could impact in the absence of anything else and the aforementioned quiet pre-Xmas trade, as almost 1 bn rolls off at 1.1070 and from 1.1100-10.

SCANDI/EM - The Swedish Crown has slipped after another test of resistance near 10.4150 against the Euro failed to propel the Sek higher, but its Norwegian peer is extending gains through 10.0000 towards 9.9150 on the back of the Norges Bank’s gently inclined depo rate path. Elsewhere, EMs are largely going through the motions in tight bands vs the Dollar.

FIXED INCOME

A busier pm docket bodes well or at least better for debt markets that appear to have run out of inspiration and impetus after their earlier exertions. Bunds are back down nearer the base of a 171.56-88 band and Gilts and hovering just a few ticks above 132.00, while US Treasuries are a tick or so off overnight highs with the very short end still underperforming in to 2 year issuance. On that note, Italian bonds have also been lagging and below par even either side of a so-so CTZ auction and in contrast to Spanish paper that is content with constructive developments on the political front. Back to what lies ahead in the 2nd half, more housing data and the Fed’s national activity index, but the pick of the bunch and often erratic looks to be durable goods.

COMMODITIES 

The energy complex remains flat/subdued amid holiday-thinned conditions after a lacklustre Asia session in light of a number of bearish supply-side factors including Friday’s increase in active rigs reported via the Baker Hughes rig count coupled with reports of a Saudi-Kuwaiti agreement to renew oil output in the shared neutral zone by year-end. WTI futures hover just above the USD 60/bbl mark whilst its Brent counterpart retains USD 66/bbl+ status at time of writing. Russian Energy Minister Novak failed to provide the complex with much impetus in early EU trade despite noting that the OPEC+ could discuss deeper oil output cut quotas at its March meeting (5th/6th) in 2020. This follows this month’s policy revision in which the cartel agreed to deeper cuts of 496k BPD starting from Q1 2020, with an extraordinary meeting in March for a review. Elsewhere, gold trades on a firmer footing with the yellow metal hovering around current session highs of ~USD 1485/oz ahead of reported trend-line resistance at ~USD 1487/oz. Copper also garnered some support from the initially softer Dollar with prices re-eying USD 2.80/lb to the upside, although the red metal’s 100 WMA rests just below the round figure at USD 2.7988/lb. Finally, Dalian iron ore rose in excess of 1.0% after key steelmaking cities in Northern China issued pollution alerts as air quality in the region deteriorates.

Saudi Arabia and Kuwait reportedly could agree to renew oil output in the shared neutral zone along the border between the countries by year-end. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak says OPEC+ could discuss cutting oil output quotas at its March 5th/6th meeting next year. Additionally, adding that global oil supply growth is to slowdown next year, notes that Russia's oil production in 2019 was 560mln tonnes, reported via RBC TV. (Newswires)

French CGT workers voted to halt output at Petroineos Lavera refinery which has a capacity of 210k bpd, according to a union official. (Newswires)

subject: China's Premier Li will study further steps to lower financing costs via RRR cuts, targeted RRR cuts, discounting and re-lending., State Media

  • And the retaliatory measures are in response to the sanctions which have been imposoed on Co's constructing Nord Stream 2 as the US Government view the project as a security risk

content:

Gilts correct higher then overtake peers, Short Sterling strip slightly flatter
content: UK debt and 3 month futures resumed Liffe on a firm footing in line with core counterparts, but after a very early wobble the 10 year benchmark surpassed its peers on the way towards setting a 132.23 intraday peak vs 131.91 at worst and Friday’s 131.77 close. However, Gilts faded some way in advance of the next upside objective in technical terms (December 12’s session best at 132.42) and Short Sterling contracts have eased back from their peaks amidst mild longer end outperformance within -1.5/+2.5 ticks, but in thin volumes across the board. Note, a blank domestic slate, but the Pound is establishing a more solid base, albeit partly due to a weaker Dollar and more leggy Euro.

analysis_details: • Note, in November Softbank took a USD 4.8bln hit from their investment in WeWork.

subject: Bunds: slow crawl amidst paltry pre-Xmas volumes
content: The 10 year German debt future has extended gains from a fractionally firmer start to the last Eurex session before the Christmas break, but in extremely low key trading conditions as turnover only just creeps over 16k lots. The core Eurozone bond recently edged up to 171.82 after breaching last Thursday's intraday high (171.66), while the equivalent cash yield has slipped under -25 bp having shrugged off marginally firmer than forecast m/m import prices. Looking ahead, no further regional data to speak of, but Italian supply is scheduled before Usd40 bn 2 year notes and US durable goods often have the potential to surprise.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
ArcelorMittal (MT NA) – Co. has agreed to a share purchase agreement regarding a 50% shipping business stake sale. (Newswires)

Adidas (ADS GY) – CEO said the Co. will post double digit profit growth in the current FY. In Q4, CEO noted that “we are growing significantly faster” than in Q3, reported via FAZ. (Newswires)

Anglo American (AAL LN) - Co. has received operating licence for Minas-Rio tailings facility in Brazil. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co’s triple combination has been approved in China for COPD. (Newswires)

Bayer (BAYN GY) - US government said the verdict on Co's Roundup case should be reversed. (Newswires) 

BHP (BHP LN) – Co announced CEO Mackenzie is to retire on March 31st 2020. (Newswires)

Banco De Sabadell (SAB SM) – Co. has transferred several of its real estate assets for around EUR 3.4bln. (Newswires)

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – CEO had no knowledge of the surveillance on ex-human resource head Goerke, according to an investigation which confirms that former-COO Bouee issued the surveillance mandate on behalf of the Co. Investigation concludes that no-other executives or board members were aware of this surveillance. (Newswires) Confirmation of earlier reports that Co. are reportedly erring in favour of stating that former COO Bouee acted alone., according to sources citing individuals with knowledge. 

Credit Agricole (ACA FP) – Co. and Santander (SAN SM) report the closure of their Caceis and Santander Securities strategic combination, announcing the creation of a major global player. Combination has EUR 3.9tln in assets under custody and EUR 2.1tln in assets under administration. (Newswires)

Ferrovial (FER SM) – Ventia stated that it will purchase Ferrovial’s Broadspectrum for AUD 485mln/USD 335mln. (Newswires)

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) – US FDA has declined to approve Co’s long acting HIV injections after the regulator questioned the treatment’s chemistry, manufacturing and controls process but not its safety. (Newswires)

Intu Properties (INTU LN) – Co. have proposed a deal for the disposal of Intu Puerto Venecia, for EUR 475.3mln. (Newswires)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – German Cabin union UFO notes that talks with Lufthansa have failed; strikes are possible anytime from now but will not strike on December 24th-26th. (Newswires)

NMC Health (NMC LN) – Co. believes that its current share price is not a fair reflection of the Co’s value. Co. will be commencing an independent third-party review to provide additional reassurance to shareholders. Co. is confident that the review will be entirely confirmatory of disclosures proved by the Co. to date. (Newswires)

Safran (SAF FP) – Co’s JV with GE (GE) is said to have agreed to manufacture more Airbus (AIR FP) engines to offset some losses from the suspensions of Boeing (BA) 737 Max production, according to source. (Newswires)

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

23rd December 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the   overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded somewhat mixed as the region once again failed to fully join in on the Christmas cheer which had propelled Wall Street to fresh record highs on Friday, with volumes light heading into the holidays. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were varied with Australia dragged by commodity-related losses and due to the adverse effects of its recent currency appreciation, while the Japanese benchmark remained afloat but with upside capped by an indecisive JPY and after Japanese Chief Cabinet Suga clarified that they have not eased export controls on South Korea. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) lacked conviction despite the announcement that China is to lower import tariffs for some products beginning January 1st and after the recent Trump-Xi call in which the leaders were said to have conducted a very good talk regarding the trade deal, although reports further noted that Chinese President Xi stated US interference is harming China’s interests and there were also downward revisions to November Chinese trade data including a wider contraction in Exports.

FTSE 100

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Co. has halted production at a Chinese Christmas card factory following reports that a message was found inside a card saying it had been packed by a foreign prisoner who are victims of forced labour. The Chinese company - Zheijian Yunguang Printing - has rebuffed claims of forced labour in prisons, according to China’s Global Times. (BBC/Global Times)

UK Telecoms – Vodafone (VOD LN) and CityFibre are reportedly on the cusp of a new deal which would boost investments in full-fibre lines; the deal could be announced by the end of the week according sources cited by the FT. (FT)

British American Tobacco (BATS LN) – Co. is said to be preparing to fight a court case regarding “modern slavery” and child labour on tobacco farms in Malawi, according to sources. Several sources stated that the Co. benefits from Malawi’s political landscape and claims some MPs run tobacco farms themselves. A source close to the matter stated that the Co’s position seems to be that its hasn’t done anything wrong and that it has done all it can to stop child labour. (Telegraph)

Cobham (COB LN) – UK government has approved Co’s GBP 5bln takeover by Advent International after it offered multiple commitments to address national security concerns. (Newswires)

Anglo American (AAL LN) -Co. has signed up to a number of commitments to align its lobbying activities more with the Paris climate change agreement, in an attempt to avoid a shareholder revolt over memberships of advocacy groups that engage in lobbying for the fossil fuel industry. (FT)

LSE (LSE LN) – Co’s FTSE4Good indices still includes G4S (GFS LN) in-spite of allegations of global labour abuse and large polluting companies. (Guardian)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

CAC

Sanofi (SAN FP) – Co. has announced that it has commenced a tender offer to purchase all shares of Synthorx (THOR) for USD 68/shr, representing an aggregate equity value of around USD 2.5bln, the acquisition is expected to be completed in Q1 2020. Sanofi plans to finance the transaction with cash on hand. Following the completion of the tender offer, a Sanofi unit will merge with Synthorx. (Newswires/Nasdaq) Note: Sanofi agreed to acquire Synthorx in early December.

Airbus (AIR FP) – India has increased their scrutiny of the Co’s A320ne jets engines; causing IndiGo to have to replace at least 130 of the 200 in use vs. Prev. estimates of 110. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Atlantia (ATL IM) – Italian Government have provisionally approved a decree to make it cheaper and simpler for contracts with road operators to be terminated by the Government; the bill requires final agreement and further measures to become definitive. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – Co. has entered into a licensing agreement with Sarepta Therapeutics in which Roche is to pau USD 750mln in cash and USD 400mln worth in equity at closing, whist Sarepta is eligible to receive up to USD 1.7bln in regulatory and sales milestones plus royalties on net sales. The agreement is to improve lives of patients living with Duchenne muscular dystrophy and is expected to close in Q1 2020. (Newswires)

Credit Suisse (CSGN SW) – Co. is to report the results of a probe today into the alleged spying of ex-human resources head Goerke. Co. are reportedly erring in favour of stating that former COO Bouee acted alone., according to sources citing individuals with knowledge. (Newswires)

subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 23rd December 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded somewhat mixed as the region once again failed to follow suit from Friday’s gains on Wall Street
  • China is to lower import tariffs on certain products beginning January 1st in which it will cut some import tariffs on 850 items
  • Reports suggested President Xi is willing to continue meeting with US President Trump
  • In FX markets, currency flows were limited owing to the lack of tier-1 data releases and lighter volumes heading into the holidays
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Durable Goods, New Home Sales, Canadian GDP and US 2yr supply

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded somewhat mixed as the region once again failed to fully join in on the Christmas cheer which had propelled Wall Street to fresh record highs on Friday, with volumes light heading into the holidays. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were varied with Australia dragged by commodity-related losses and due to the adverse effects of its recent currency appreciation, while the Japanese benchmark remained afloat but with upside capped by an indecisive JPY and after Japanese Chief Cabinet Suga clarified that they have not eased export controls on South Korea. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) lacked conviction despite the announcement that China is to lower import tariffs for some products beginning January 1st and after the recent Trump-Xi call in which the leaders were said to have conducted a very good talk regarding the trade deal, although reports further noted that Chinese President Xi stated US interference is harming China’s interests and there were also downward revisions to November Chinese trade data including a wider contraction in Exports. Finally, 10yr JGBs languished firmly below the 152.00 level after the recent bear-flattening in USTs and with demand also dampened by the lack of BoJ presence in the market today. 

 

PBoC injected CNY 50bln via 14-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY 50bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set USD/CNY reference rate at 7.0117 vs. Exp. 7.0119 (Prev. 7.0020)

 

Chinese President Xi reportedly told US President Trump that US interference is harming Chinese interests and expressed concerns regarding the US stance on Taiwan, while other reports noted that President Xi is willing to continue meeting with US President Trump. (Xinhua/China Daily/Hong Kong Daily)

 

China is to lower import tariffs on certain products beginning January 1st in which it will cut some import tariffs on 850 items and will further lower import tariffs for some IT products from July 1st. Furthermore, it was also reported that China is taking a major step to open up sectors ranging from oil and gas to telecoms and railways by easing market regulations and reducing financing costs for private companies, with the government to offer more tax breaks and broaden incentives to more firms. (Xinhua)

 

US Commerce Secretary Ross said the US has been very careful on providing exclusions to the Huawei entity list and reiterated the US could increase tariffs on China if they do not hold up to the trade deal. (Newswires)

 

China Global Times tweeted that China would reduce import tariffs even without the phase-one deal as it is seeking a more cooperative and inclusive global trade environment, citing Beijing Economic Operation Association Vice Director Tian Yun. (Twitter)

 

China November USD-denominated trade data revisions: Trade Balance revised to 37.93B (Prev. 38.73B), Exports revised to -1.3% (Prev. -1.1%), Imports revised to 0.5% (Prev. 0.3%). (Newswires)

Japanese Chief Cabinet Secretary Suga clarified that they have not eased export controls on South Korea and that the change to controls are just procedural. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

ECB's Knot said cannot dismiss worrying prospect of current low interest rates lasting another half-decade and that low interest rate policy risks becoming counterproductive, while he added that the ECB have to reassess policy in time. (Newswires)

 

FX

In FX markets, currency flows all but dried out owing to the lack of tier-1 data releases and lighter volumes heading into the holidays which saw the DXY little changed as its major counterparts traded mixed, with EUR/USD dejected after its recent slip to below 1.1100 and with GBP/USD off Friday’s worst levels as it battled to retain the 1.3000 handle after the House of Commons overwhelmingly voted to approve the second reading of PM Johnson's Brexit deal. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses mirrored the mixed risk appetite, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD slightly outperformed after having reclaimed the 0.6900 and 0.6600 handles respectively in the aftermath of the recent encouraging data releases across the Tasman, although some analysts remained unconvinced including JPMorgan which sees potential for QE by the RBA in Q4 2020.

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed amid a similar overnight risk sentiment owing to the holiday-thinned conditions in which WTI crude futures marginally extended on Friday’s losses on bearish supply side factors including an increase in the number of Baker Hughes oil rigs and following reports of a potential Saudi-Kuwait agreement to resume output from the shared neutral zone by year-end, which had been idled for over 3 years and has a daily capacity of 500k bpd. Elsewhere, gold mildly benefitted from the uneventful greenback and revisited last week’s highs, while copper trickled back below the USD 2.80/lb level with prices hampered by the broad indecision.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (20th Dec): Oil +18 at 685, Natgas -4 at 125, Total +14 at 813. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia and Kuwait reportedly could agree to renew oil output in the shared neutral zone along the border between the countries by year-end. (Newswires)

French CGT workers voted to halt output at Petroineos Lavera refinery which has a capacity of 210k bpd, according to a union official. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Syrian anti-aircraft defence fired at hostile missiles which allegedly came from Israel. (Newswires)

Center for Strategic and International Studies’ Victor Cha said possible launch sites in North Korea look that they are basically ready to go. (Twitter)

North Korean Leader Kim Jong Un is expected to take a ‘wait and see’ approach regarding making a deal with the US due to US President Trump being politically vulnerable (impeachment & 2020 election); if Trump were to win another term North Korea may be more likely to return to negotiations., according to a source familiar with North Korean leadership. Adding, that the likely hood of a proactive test is ‘very low’ as this would be too confrontational for China and Russia. (CNN)

US 

The bias was slightly towards bear-flattening, although yields were up by around 1bps or so. Traders attributed the unrevised Q3 GDP print, with the data also revealing consumer spending better than expected, and businesses spending on non-residential structures, like power infrastructure, wires noted. The small upward revision in Michigan sentiment was also said to be a contributing factor. The theme this week has been steepening of 2s10s, although that wasn't seen on Friday, with many desks wrapping up for the year, there was a quiet feel to Treasury trade, which may again be seen in the early part of next week, before the Christmas holidays. US T-note futures (H0) settled 2 ticks lower at 128-08.

US President Trump signed the USD 1.4tln spending bill on Friday to avert the government shutdown as expected. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia lacks conviction amid lighter volumes heading into the holidays
content:
Asia equity markets trade somewhat mixed as the region once again fails to fully join in on the Christmas cheer which had propelled Wall Street to fresh record highs on Friday, with volumes light heading into the holidays. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) are varied with Australia dragged by commodity-related losses and due to the adverse effects of its recent currency appreciation, while the Japanese benchmark remains afloat but with upside capped by an indecisive JPY and after Japanese Chief Cabinet Suga clarified that they have not eased export controls on South Korea. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) lack conviction despite the announcement that China is to lower import tariffs for some products beginning January 1st and after the recent Trump-Xi call in which they were said to have conducted a very good talk regarding the China trade deal, although reports further noted that Chinese President Xi stated US interference is harming China’s interests and there were also downward revisions to November trade data including a wider contraction in Exports of -1.3% (Prev. -1.1%).

In FX markets, price action has all but dried out owing to the lack of tier-1 data releases and lighter volumes heading into the holidays in which the DXY is little changed as its major counterparts are mixed, with EUR/USD languishing after its recent slip to below 1.1100 and with GBP/USD off Friday’s worst levels but struggling to retain the 1.3000 handle after the House of Commons overwhelmingly voted to approve the second reading of PM Johnson's Brexit deal through a 358 v 234 vote, which sets up the bill debate for January. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses mirror the mixed risk appetite, while AUD/USD and NZD/USD slightly outperform after having reclaimed the 0.6900 and 0.6600 handles respectively in the aftermath of the recent encouraging data releases across the Tasman, although some analysts remain unconvinced including JPMorgan which sees potential QE by the RBA in Q4 2020.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued and languish firmly below the 152.00 level after the recent bear-flattening in USTs and with demand also dampened by the lack of BoJ presence in the market today.
